author: Alok K N Mishra
title: Police complaint against V K Singh for 'dog remark' - The Times of India
text:
RANCHI: A police complaint was lodged against Union minister of state for external affairs General V K Singh for his controversial 'dog remark', that came after the killing of two dalit kids in a Haryana village, in Jamshedpur's Parsudih police station on Saturday.
The East Singhbhum district president of Jharkhand Dishom Party (JDP) Junior Murmu lodged the complaint and demanded an FIR be registered against Singh under SC/ST (prevention of atrocities) Act.
Officer-in-charge of Parsudih police station B K Chaturvedi said a complaint demanding action against the minister was lodged. A copy was also sent to Jamshedpur SSP.
"The statements of the minister have psychologically and emotionally hurt the tribal and people of scheduled caste. It is a criminal act," said JDP chief Salkhan Murmu on whose advice the police complaint was lodged. The complainant cited the reports of the Times of India as evidence for the complaint.
A copy of the complaint.
The complainant demanded punishment for Singh under various sections of SC/ST (prevention of atrocities) amendment ordinance 2014 for intentionally insulting SC/ST members and attempting to promote hatred and ill-will against them.
In a remark at Ghaziabad, the Lok Saha constituency Singh represents, about Faridabad incident in which two children were burnt alive, Singh said the incident was a case of personal feud and it should be checked if there had been an administrative lapse. He went on to say, "For everything...like if somebody throws a stone at a dog, then the government is responsible...it is not like that."
Singh's remarks have kicked up a storm and opposition parties are using the remarks to attack BJP everywhere especially in Bihar where assembly elections are going on. Stay updated on the go with Times of India News App. Click here to download it for your device.
